stem: A client with deep-vein thrombosis and malnutrition has been receiving specialized TPN (high-lipid) for 4 weeks. Based on the documentation in the Liver Function & TPN Surveillance Log, what is the best interpretation of the current labs and assessment findings?

options.text: The client is experiencing TPN-induced end-stage hepatic failure with encephalopathy.
The elevated ammonia level is a normal byproduct of high-protein TPN administration.
The jaundice is caused by the breakdown of red blood cells (hemolysis).
The prolonged PT is due to a Vitamin C deficiency.

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing **fulminant hepatic failure associated with long-term TPN use (a1)**. The elevated ammonia level (112 mcg/dL) and asterixis (flapping tremors) confirm **Hepatic Encephalopathy**. Long-term, non-cycled TPN (24/7 lipid infusion) can lead to severe steatohepatitis (fatty liver inflammation) and cholestasis, eventually causing liver failure. The prolonged PT and low platelet count (thrombocytopenia) further support the lack of hepatic synthetic function.
clinicalPearls: Ammonia is a neurotoxin; elevated levels can cross the blood-brain barrier, leading to confusion and coma.
Asterixis, also known as the 'Liver Flap,' is a hallmark sign of Stage II encephalopathy.
Cycling TPN (allowing the liver hours without fat/glucose infusion) is the best way to prevent this complication.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the elevated ammonia level is solely due to the TPN amino acids (a2).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While amino acids are broken down into ammonia, a healthy liver converts ammonia to urea for excretion. An ammonia level of 112 mcg/dL indicates the liver is not effectively converting ammonia, making it an abnormal finding.

mnemonic.title: Flap & Fail
mnemonic.expansion: Asterixis (Flap). Ammonia (Brain fog). ALT (Liver kill). TPN (The cause).

exhibits.title: Nursing Physical
exhibits.content: Current: Client is difficult to arouse (Stage II Encephalopathy). Flapping tremors (Asterixis) noted when hands are extended. Sclera are deeply jaundiced. No prior history of alcohol use or hepatitis.

exhibits.title: Medication History
exhibits.content: Note: TPN includes a 20% lipid emulsion administered continuously (24 hours/day). Client has received no oral intake for 30 days.
